nexttext:
where it is understood that $\beta_{{\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{{X}}}}} = \beta_k$ if ${\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{{X}}}} \in \Phi_k$. Consider the event $E_k(r)$ that $A^\star = k$ and $R^\star = r$, i.e., $E_k(r)$ is the event that the test user is associated to a tier-$k$ BS at a distance $r$ under the BARSS association policy.  It is easy to see that the locations of BSs in tier-$i$ form a homogeneous PPP over ${\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{{R}}}}}}^2 \backslash \mathcal{B}\left({{\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{{0}}}}, Q_i^{(k)}(r)}\right)$ given the event $E_k(r)$ for $i=1, \ldots, K$, where $Q_i^{(k)}(r) = G_i^{-1}\left({\frac{\beta_k P_k}{\beta_i P_i} G_k(r)}\right)$, and $G_i^{-1}(y) = \inf\left\{{x \geq 0: G_i(x) = y}\right\}$ if $y \in \left[{0, G_i(0)}\right]$ and zero otherwise. 
This observation puts us back to the generic association policy framework, and the derivation of the bounds for the conditional outage probability/capacity on the conditioned event $E_k(r)$ proceeds as before. Averaging over the event $E_k(r)$, we obtain the bounds for the unconditional outage probability and capacity metrics. To this end, we need the following lemmas. 
\begin{lem} \label{Lemma: Gauss Approximation for BARSS Policy}
Under the BARSS association policy described above, for all $x \in {\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{{R}}}}}}$,

where it is understood that $\beta_{{\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{{X}}}}} = \beta_k$ if ${\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{{X}}}} \in \Phi_k$. Consider the event $E_k(r)$ that $A^\star = k$ and $R^\star = r$, i.e., $E_k(r)$ is the event that the test user is associated to a tier-$k$ BS at a distance $r$ under the BARSS association policy.  It is easy to see that the locations of BSs in tier-$i$ form a homogeneous PPP over ${\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{{R}}}}}}^2 \backslash \mathcal{B}\left({{\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{{0}}}}, Q_i^{(k)}(r)}\right)$ given the event $E_k(r)$ for $i=1, \ldots, K$, where $Q_i^{(k)}(r) = G_i^{-1}\left({\frac{\beta_k P_k}{\beta_i P_i} G_k(r)}\right)$, and $G_i^{-1}(y) = \inf\left\{{x \geq 0: G_i(x) = y}\right\}$ if $y \in \left[{0, G_i(0)}\right]$ and zero otherwise. 
This observation puts us back to the generic association policy framework, and the derivation of the bounds for the conditional outage probability/capacity on the conditioned event $E_k(r)$ proceeds as before. Averaging over the event $E_k(r)$, we obtain the bounds for the unconditional outage probability and capacity metrics. To this end, we need the following lemmas. 
\begin{lem} \label{Lemma: Gauss Approximation for BARSS Policy}
Under the BARSS association policy described above, for all $x \in {\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{{R}}}}}}$,

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E4.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="f_{k}(u)=\frac{2\pi\lambda_{k}}{p_{k}^{\star}}\sum_{j=1}^{K}u\exp\left({-\pi%
